Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research PEEC: 2+2+2+Infinity: Pipeline for Tribal Pre-Engineering to Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaboration among TCUP colleges Cankdeska Cikana Community College Community
College, CCCC, Ft. Berthold Community College, FBCC, Turtle Mountain Community College ,
TMCC, and Sitting Bull College, SBC, and North Dakota State University, NDSU, is the
culmination of more than 11 years of active engagement in STEM education on the reservation,
including a year-long academic sabbatical at TMCC by an engineering professor. It supports a
tribal college vision of expanded life-choices for reservation residents that could provide more
technical competency for tribal decision-making, infrastructure improvement and the
opportunity for personal and tribal advancement without loss of cultural heritage. For NDSU
the benefits would include expanded participation of culturally diverse students, shared
fulfillment of the 1862/1994 land grant mission, improved faculty-student communication and
interaction and expansion of the talent pool entering STEM professions. The heart of the
proposal is the interaction of tribal high school, tribal college, mainstream University and
engineering profession stakeholders to facilitate the recruitment, education and support of
tribal students to acquire and hone the skills that will allow them to enter the engineering
profession or contribute in some other fashion to their communities and the nation. The
proposal will accomplish this vision by impacting students through interactions with faculty/
staff, curriculum and supporting functions/agencies. All of this will be accomplished in a
culturally supportive fashion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PEEC program involves a collaboration between four tribal colleges (Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College, Turtle Mountain Community College, Sitting Bull College, and CCCC). These four TCU’s revolve around a mainstream institution (NDSU) to round out the collaborative. The aim of this cooperative effort is to have each TCU provide its own 2-year program in pre-engineering culminating in an Associates of Science Degree for students who complete the academic requirements. During this time the students will have instructors from each of the partnering colleges teach them core classes through the interactive video network (IVN).  After this initial step, they go onto the College of Engineering at NDSU and major in the engineering discipline of their choice (mechanical, civil, electrical, etc.) with the goal of obtaining a 4-year baccalaureate degree. Ideally, they should be able to enter NDSU as juniors if they finish the program of study at their respective TCU. Many however, will transfer to NDSU before they have all the credits to actually get an AS degree. Regardless of the path they take, the TCU is still an important initial step for them in their pathway to a terminal degree. One of the goals of the PEEC TCU is to act as a transitional phase from the reservation community to a mainstream institution. It exposes them to the mainstream campus environment gradually as they travel to NDSU, as well as the other TCU’s, to meet fellow students and various professors they will eventually have in future course work. They also come in contact with the student services available to them at NDSU. In all, they find a support structure in place that will help them not only survive the four-year institution, but also to thrive there.

The outcomes of this seven-year NSF grant funded project stem from the two initial goals set forth:

   Goal #1: To establish a self-sustainable pre-engineering program at the tribal community college level that culminates in an Associate of Science degree, which then allows the student to transfer to a four-year institution to earn a Baccalaureate of Science in engineering.

   The outcome of this goal are four community college pre-engineering programs, each with qualified faculty and established and approved programs of study solidified within their respective campuses with the technical infrastructure in place to perform distance education amongst themselves as well as with any other institution of higher learning within the state. The credits earned from these programs, whether general education credits or core engineering credits, are all transferrable to four-year mainstream institutions through articulation agreements which mean the TCU is providing the complete first two years of requirements toward a baccalaureate degree in engineering. The sustainability issue is more difficult to ascertain at this point in time. With the above outcomes having been put in place and seven years of operations being implemented, one does not want to give the program a ‘sink or swim’ option. Outreach to the feeder schools in the local area, especially those serving the reservation, has always been challenged with producing results but new ideas being implemented show promise of more success in placing new students into the PEEC pathway.   

   Goal #2: To demonstrate to tribal members the advantages of having fellow members among them who are trained engineers in positions of influence on the reservation where they can apply their expertise to any number of problems, technical or otherwise.

Two CCCC graduates in PEEC have come back to the Spirit Lake Reservation after attending NDSU. One has a degree in civil engineering whereas the other decided to come back to the reservation before completing his mechanical degree. One is a project manager for Spirit Lake Tribal Planning and the other works for the Tribal EPA. These two young men have shown themselves extremely capable in the positions given to them, which are in areas of directly improving the living conditions on the reservation. Besides their technical contributions to the local community, both are outstanding role models to the young people of the tribe by volunteering their services in the areas of coaching in sports and other community contributions. If any elder were asked, without a doubt, they would show a desire for more individuals like these to return to their home and be the next generational leaders in the community.
